column1: The official coat of arms of the city dates back to the Austrian rule and the 18th century. It is derived from the coat of arms of the District of Velika Kikinda which was issued by Maria Theresa of Austria on 12 November 1774. The Coat of Arms represents a hand holding a sabre on which an Ottoman Turkish head is impaled. It symbolizes the fight of Serbs and the majority ethnic Hungarians at that time
column2: against the Turks during the Military Frontier period and the military contributions of the population of Kikinda during the Austro-Ottoman Wars.
Branislav Blažić
column3: then president of the municipality of Kikinda
column4: asked for the change of the coat of arms
column5: criticizing it for being "morbid". The idea proved very controversial
column6: and ultimately the coat was not changed. Most critics of Blažić stated that the coat of arms is a part of the history and tradition of Kikinda and so an important factor of the city identity.The severed head of a Turk is also one of the common symbols in Austrian and Hungarian heraldry. It symbolizes the struggle of Serb soldiers of the Habsburg Empire (Austrian Empire) against the Ottoman Empire during the Austro-Ottoman Wars.

column1: The city belongs to the group of so-called planned organized settlements. The Suvača is a horse-powered dry mill. Kikinda has one of the three remaining such mills in Europe (the other two being in Szarvas
column2: Hungary and Otok). There were many mills like this in the city
column3: the largest recorded number being 51 in 1847. The only remaining mill was built in 1899 and was operational until 1945.Located in the center of the square

column5: the late baroque iconostasis and the wall paintings show significant influence of western European art of the period. New church bells were installed in 1899.

column1: Serbian Orthodox Holy Trinity monastery is located in the south outskirts of the city. It was built between 1885 and 1887 as a foundation of Melanija Nikolić-Gajčić. The construction of the Roman Catholic Church in Kikinda was started in 1808 and completed in 1811.

column1: The Pumpkin Days (Дани лудаје/Dani ludaje in Serbian) are an annual manifestation that takes place in mid-October. Every year people from all over the region gather in Kikinda to take part in a competition of who has the largest pumpkin and longest gourd. The term ludaja is specific to the Kikinda region
column2: while the common Serbian word for pumpkin is bundeva. Kikinda has a special relationship with this plant because throughout its history
column3: the locals used to say that one had to stand on a pumpkin while working in the fields in order to get a clear view of the whole city. This exaggeration is supposed to depict the flatness of the city's territory and symbolize the joy of finding way back home. A local man standing on a pumpkin
column5: and with his hand blocking the sun so that he can see into the distance
column6: thus became the symbol of the region. A group of local enthusiasts started the Pumpkin Days celebration in 1986 and it quickly started attracting pumpkin and gourd lovers from all over the country. The three-day event also includes lectures and seminars on the advancement of pumpkin and gourd cultivation
column7: a culinary competition in preparing meals from pumpkins and gourds
column8: children's competitions in creating masks and sculptures
column9: and various concerts and exhibitions. Over the past few years this event has gained prominence and has drawn visitors from Hungary
column10: Romania and the former Yugoslav republics. The largest pumpkin measured at the event to date weighed 247 kg (545 lb)
column11: while the longest gourd was 213 centimeters in length. In 2006 the event celebrated its 20th anniversary and had the largest number of visitors so far
column12: as well as a richer program. A tamburitza festival was included in the event
column13: contributing to the authentic Banat experience.
